page.title: 17SCOTLAND'S ROYAL OBSERVATORY
page.content: Today on a 4 acre site on Blackford Hill you will find the Astromony Department of Edinburgh University. When opened in 1896 to replace the Calton Hill Observatory it gave work for 4 scientists. Now there are over 100. Overseas telescopes now provide most of the information, satellites in orbit relay this information and in a few hours the Cosmos machine can measure observations that would take a scientist 7 years. Two very large computers proces the figures. At Siding Spring in Australia the UK Schmidt Telescope takes wide angled photographs of the sky. Our astonomers have made a sky atlas from these. At Mauna Kea in Hawaii, the UK infrared telescope is worked by scientists who do not ever have to leave Blackford Hill.
